Amazon.co.uk Review:
Although 19-year old Kane Robinson is the latest product of the vibrant UK Garage scene commonly dubbed "grime", his deceptively named debut full-length album, Home Sweet Home travels far beyond the East London boroughs most grime MCs make their ends. Boasting collaborative work with The StreetsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Mike Skinner, M.I.A associate Diplo, grime faces Terrah Danjah and D Double E, and even producer du jour Paul Epworth Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the Bloc Party knob-twiddler, who contributes Black Sabbath-sampling rock banger "I DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Know Why" Ã¢â‚¬â€œ this is an album that reflects KanoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charismatic, multi-faced style: or, as he neatly puts it on frothing junglist number "Reload It", "I make love music/And I make thug music".

Skipping styles like hopscotch, we see Kano tackle assured, chugging rap-rock ("Typical Me"); Latin-tinged, Hennesy-sipping party vibes ("Remember Me"); reflective garden-gate philosophy ("How We LivinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢"); and thuggish, slice-of-London-life drama (Ã¢â‚¬ËœGhetto KidÃ¢â‚¬â„¢) with equal charm and proficiency. His debut single, "Boys Love Girls" Ã¢â‚¬â€œ a bouncy, comical encapsulation of playground sexual politics, included here as a bonus track Ã¢â‚¬â€œ still sounds like perhaps his finest moment. But on Home Sweet Home, Kano has grown in many directions, and somewhat miraculously, every one suits him --Louis Pattison
